docs.lead_paragraph: When the president delivers his address, an early sign of where things stand may come from watching the applause -- or lack thereof -- from members of Congress. One senator worth keeping an eye on is Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska, who often finds a seat near the front row at such major speeches.
docs.abstract: Sen Ben Nelson says it would be difficult for him to vote for overhaul of health care system that did not have bipartisan support; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Holidays have long been risky times to share the roads, and statistics show that drinking and driving is a major reason. Last year during Labor Day weekend, 40 percent of all fatal crashes involved a drunken driver, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline.main: Arrests of Women for Drunken Driving Are on the Rise

docs.abstract: A recent government report highlights a disturbing new trend: the number of women arrested for driving drunk is on the rise.
docs.snippet: A recent government report highlights a disturbing new trend: the number of women arrested for driving drunk is on the rise.

docs.lead_paragraph: When it comes to paying for dental care, patients don't get much help, reports Walecia Konrad in the latest Patient Money column.

headline.main: Taking Care of Teeth on a Budget

docs.abstract: Dental care costs are rising faster than inflation, just as the evidence mounts that taking care of your mouth can be a critical gateway to good overall health. Here's how to make that trip to the dentist more affordable.
docs.snippet: Dental care costs are rising faster than inflation, just as the evidence mounts that taking care of your mouth can be a critical gateway to good overall health. Here's how to make that trip to the dentist more affordable.

docs.lead_paragraph: With President Obama preparing an address to a joint session of Congress next week, hoping to reclaim the health care debate, his aides have indicated that he will be far more "prescriptive" in detailing what he wants included in the final legislation.

headline.main: Obama, Clinton and the Bill Not Written

docs.abstract: Was the White House right to avoid writing its own health care bill?
docs.snippet: Was the White House right to avoid writing its own health care bill?

docs.lead_paragraph: The battle over reforming the nation's health care system hit home yesterday.

headline.main: The Day: Divided Over Health Care

docs.abstract: Congressman Bill Pascrell's Town Hall meeting on health care reform turned into a heated debate, with no clear consensus in sight.
docs.snippet: Congressman Bill Pascrell's Town Hall meeting on health care reform turned into a heated debate, with no clear consensus in sight.

docs.lead_paragraph: The unemployment rate rose last month to 9.7 percent from a dip in July, according to the latest report issued by the Labor Department this Friday morning.

headline.main: The Early Word: Unemployment Rate Goes Up

docs.abstract: Even as the pace of job losses slows a bit, the rate went up to 9.7 percent last month.
docs.snippet: Even as the pace of job losses slows a bit, the rate went up to 9.7 percent last month.

byline.original: By JANIE LORBER and KATE PHILLIPS

docs.lead_paragraph: People who don't have insurance, but aren't poor enough to meet federal poverty standards, may not get any chance for new coverage under the health care bills now circulating in Congress, the economist Uwe E. Reinhardt notes in a column posted Friday morning on the Economix blog. So that means they may still be overly reliant on hospital emergency rooms - and vulnerable to the extra-high charges that E.R.'s often levy against the uninsured. Here's what he's talking about.

headline.main: Where's the 'Reform' for High E.R. Charges for the Uninsured?

docs.abstract: The uninsured continue to receive the highest bills from hospital emergency rooms, writes the economist Uwe E. Rheinhardt.
docs.snippet: The uninsured continue to receive the highest bills from hospital emergency rooms, writes the economist Uwe E. Rheinhardt.

docs.lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

headline.main: Ending Hospital Price Discrimination Against the Uninsured

docs.abstract: An economist's proposal to cap the amount hospitals can charge the uninsured for care.
docs.snippet: An economist's proposal to cap the amount hospitals can charge the uninsured for care.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama has drifted away from tackling the real problem with health care: perverse incentives.
docs.snippet: President Obama has drifted away from tackling the real problem with health care: perverse incentives.
